answers.answer: Hi--I'm not a physician or a nurse and don't know the statistics and specifics.But I do know that a year ago, my Dad, who just turned 84, had his aortic valve replaced, triple bypass, and a portion of his aorta removed due to a transthoracic aneurysm. They did all this in one surgery which lasted I think about 4 hours.He made it through the surgery (though recovery was a bit slower than what was expected because he waited too long to have the surgery and his diabetes was a bit of a problem), and today he is as sassy as ever!Good luck.

An enlarged ascending aorta and aorta valve are usually done at the same time as most of the time there is a correlation with the two disorders (is the condition a bicuspid aorta?).  A surgeon will do the bypass at the same time if necessary.  It is difficult to assign any risk to surgery as there are many variables...skill of the surgeon, general health of the individual, etc.  Your surgeon should inform you of the risk/benefit.  It is considered wise to select a surgeon that has had at least a thousand similar surgeries without any associated problems.  That would indicate the risk is less than a thousand to one or .001 risk.
